name Mark. Just at the top I'm just going to say I'm Marcia Armani the
interviewer with Gareth Davis with an I or an E? Of course.
Is that the Welsh version? Well absolutely. And we're at Caleon and it is
Monday April 29 2019 and we're here to interview Dr. Mark Lewis. Mark so I'm
just going to pop that there. I wonder if you could just introduce yourself. Who
you are, what you do. Okay I'm Dr. Mark Lewis. I'm the senior curator of Roman
archaeology at the National Museum of Wales based at the National Roman
Legion Museum in Caleon. We hold all the Roman material from the two legionary
bases in Wales that happen to be very close together at Usk nearby and Caleon
where this museum is based. So we only hold Roman objects in our collections
and anything that's later any medieval material is sent off to the National
Museum in Cardiff because we are part of the National Museum of Wales but we hold
all the Roman material from those two legionary bases. There is a third Welsh
legionary base but it was built on the wrong side of the River Dee on the wrong
bank by the Romans so it's Chester and had it been on the other bank it would
be in Wales but it is our counterpart in the north if you like it's a very
similar geographical location at the lowest crossing point of the Dee and
took its name after the river Diva, Dewa, after the Dee and Isca, Caleon
Isca was named after the Usk. So we do have these mirror image fortresses at
either end of Wales but sadly as far as the National Museum is concerned the
great collections and great fortress of Chester just happened to be on
the wrong bank so they're in England in the modern boundary is along the river.
So your interest in Roman, where does that come from?
Well I grew up on the edge of the levels in Caldecott and of course Caldecott is
adjacent to the great Roman city of Carwent, our tribal capital and I had a
fabulous inspirational history teacher when I went to Caldecott comprehensive
school who you will have met Peter Strong. He was my history teacher at the
age of 11 and on Sunday mornings he used to take the school minibus to an
excavation at Trostry near Usk and we used to dig and we were taught to dig
there from the age of 11, a group of us. Many of my contemporaries fell away as
time went by and as winters approached because we dug all the way through the
year at Trostry but he kept going, I kept going for three years and that took me
up to my teenage years when I was old enough to join the Roman excavations at
Carwent that were being undertaken by the National Museum of Wales and
directed by Richard Brewer the then keeper of Roman archaeology. So at the
age of 15 I joined the excavations in Carwent and because they happened during
the summer during school holidays I was able to continue to excavate there
through my GCSEs, through my A levels and even into when I was studying for my
degree for nine seasons in all. So that's where I got my love for Roman
archaeology and where I really sharpened my digging skills to become a
competent field archaeologist. What an inspirational teacher. Absolutely and I
think individuals, individual characters are absolutely critical. Somebody will
somewhere in their lives meet someone that that gives them that spark of
inspiration or then mentors them to develop it and Peter, I was very lucky I
had a number, there was also a local gentleman that used to come to that dig
from Rogget again on the edge of the levels called Barry Stopgate and he was
a very much a historian and archaeologist but interested in vernacular
architecture so farmhouses, old farmhouses and old farm buildings. So very
soon having Doug alongside Barry for years and years and years I was holding
the other end of his measuring tapes as we surveyed all the ancient farmhouses
the Tudor and Jacobean farmhouses on the levels and on the south of the county.
The farmhouses in the north of the county had been surveyed by Lord Raglan
and Sir Cyril Fox of the National Museum in the early part of the 19th century
but they'd never come down to the south of Monmouthshire so we started picking
off a number of the houses. I joined Barry who'd been studying these houses
for some time so private individuals would give us access to their own
homes and we'd measure them, survey them accurately, look at the internal features
like ancient fireplaces, staircases, plaster ceilings in some cases, paneled
Tudor paneled passageways etc and we would photograph them, measure them and
then write them up and many of those reports are deposited in the local
library service. So these characters are inspirational and one thing leads
to another and without them and the inspiration from my own father used to
take me to all these places and give me access and do much especially on the
landscape side of things in understanding how things fit together in a landscape
context. Well when I went to university one of the things we were taught very
early on was a new sort of theory in archaeology that was called a
phenomenology of landscape and it was the way that people move about in
landscapes and then start to attach meaning or importance to certain
features within landscapes. Perhaps they mark passageways between the summer
grazing or the winter grazing, perhaps they mark out territory where people lay
claim to grazing rights through the positions of their chambered tombs, the
early farmers, the first monuments within our landscape that we can still see
today. So people started to place monuments, their burial mounds with
respect to certain views from them so that they could look down on their
former territory and life from the grave etc. So there's a relationship
between the archaeology, the monuments and where they're positioned within the
landscape perhaps with respect to ancient communication routes, the road
system etc. And my father had always intuitively been very very knowledgeable
and thoroughly understood that aspect of landscape and so when I went to
university and they taught this as really quite modern theory that had only
been published about the time I was at university I was immediately overjoyed
that I thoroughly understood this because this is the way I'd been trained
but I was immediately depressed that I hadn't published it first because I fully
understood this new theory because this is the way I viewed archaeology and had
been raised to view it. And so it's a number of factors that have brought
me along the path that I now tread but those early mentors and that
early inspiration was key to really getting me going on the journey.
Feel free to ask questions Gareth.
Thank you, yes I will. It's just interesting that you've drawn the archaeology and
geomorphology really together. How do you see that fitting in possibly when we look
at the landscape on the levels?
I think, and for me it's the way I think that we can best understand the interaction
between man and our landscape or that particular landscape in the past but the
importance that I place on the levels is not wholly historical. It's the fact that
it can inform our futures globally actually not just locally. I think if we
take the lessons and our understandings of the pasts on the levels at different
points in time and we project them forward in the knowledge that the
current predictions are for continued global sea level rise, temperature rise
and the commensurate sea level rise that will come with that on a global
basis then we can look at the way the levels have been affected by sea level
rise, the coming and going of the high mean water spring tide over time and
project what that will mean for people on the levels and elsewhere in the
future because people in the past have had the ability to move in and out of
this landscape. In the Iron Age and before the Neolithic farmers, the Iron
Age farmers even as far back as the Mesolithic, the Middle Stone Age, people
moved in and out of the tidal zone if you like and the flood plains of
the levels. It would be very much a summer grazing area for pastoral farming.
Very little if any arable, no evidence really for arable, very very localized
probably places like the higher ground like Goldcliff Island and otherwise on
the Fen Edge and this is shown again in a landscape sense by the positions of
the early Norman churches. If you look at the earliest churches in southern
Monmouthshire they sit along the Fen Edge right on the edge where the level meets
the rising ground up off the flood plain so you start off with places like
St. Pierre, Mathen, you move along then Port Scuett right on the edge where
the ground starts to rise up off the flood plain. Caldecott again securely
just up off the water meadows where the castle sits and then you travel along
to the two rogues again on the very edge. Undie again right on the edge so
close to the railway line which again was then placed right at the edge on the
slightly higher rising ground and of course the M4 is even further inland
but again hugs that higher ground. So people move from the winter grazing on
the higher land, the less boggy areas down to this very very fertile rich flood
plain the levels for summer grazing. So you've got this transhumance as
it's called the movement of livestock and people in and out of the landscape.
If it floods you move out, if it is dry then you can utilize it
for grazing. Well the issues we have with the intensification of land use and with
population rises that people don't really want to move in and out of areas
anymore and they economically they're not able to do so. We're quite sedentary,
we're quite fixed within landscapes and the problem that we have is that the
landscape of the levels is pretty much fossilized at its ancient levels, Roman
ground level covered by about half a meter of later clay inundation from
inundations later on and very little since the land is at a certain level but
the sea has continued to rise very slowly since the end of the last ice
age and the current concerns with regard to global warming are that it
seems to be rising more quickly now since the industrial age, the dawn of
the industrial age then if the land stays at the same level but sea level
and high tides are rising higher and higher you become more and more reliant
upon sea defenses until you can't rely on them anymore because eventually it
might catch up with them. If you have a failure of a low sea defense it's not
that catastrophic usually the water will flood in it will flow back out again
but if you build astronomically high sea defenses and there's a there's a failure
of the sea defense then it can be quite catastrophic because then you start to
get more tsunami like waves that sweep across the landscape so the idea of just
raising sea walls ever higher is probably not the way to approach any
future sea level rise so I think if we take lessons from the past and look at
when the levels were first defended when they were first first attempts at
drainage were made on a large scale to improve the land and then to defend it
from the sea we can start to look at what the futures may be for different
areas of the levels if the current trend for sea level rise continues.

But what did that feel like and were you aware then of the age?

something since it was last handled then you wonder how it was deposited who
went through the process of depositing it and what their thoughts may have been
probably thoughtlessly just just getting rid of as much rubbish as they can into
the ditch they had their own cares and worries and then probably diseases so it
opens up a whole world of possibilities as to what the back story for that tiny
little pot should might have been how was it broken in the first place and
where on earth is the rest of it because it's so common that you'll find one
piece of a pot if I break something in the kitchen I sweep it all up and I
deposit it together but somehow over time things often don't find their way
into the ground as parts of the whole deposited together often you just find
one part and just make you wonder what happened to the rest of it hasn't turned
to dust so it's all out there somewhere it's just there waiting to be found

who who made that wall where what were their lives like it's lovely to hear you

the ground in the middle of the Basilica so between the two colonnades of what
would have looked like a modern Cathedral really with two aisles and a
knave down the middle it would have stood at least 15 meters high very very
tall building a huge I'll haul and in the middle in the foundation levels the
the the natural soil was a hole with an X shaped slot that settled or being cut
down into the clay and I just dug what was there and that's what it produced a
hole like a with an X a big X in the ground I didn't know what it was but the
director knew immediately what it was because one had been found at London and
it was the impression in the soil that had been left by the crane that the
Romans had used to raise the column drums on top to build the colonnade so
because he knew now where the crane sat in the middle to do the two columns on
either side he knew where the columns were as they'd gone and because he knew
the spacing from the end wall of where that those columns were because of the
position of the crane he could tell where the columns were how many they were
how equally spaced they were and because of the way Roman
architecture works he could then calculate the height of the building so
it became apparent to me very early on it's not a treasure hunt for the staff
it's about the information that we can gain through this process so my best
discovery in many ways or certainly one of the best was was not an object at all
it was just a shape in the soil in the ground a slightly different colored soil
with a slightly different texture that we were able to follow the shape of and
it gave us the indentation in the ground where a Roman crane has been
set up maybe only for a day or two but it that that impression was sealed
beneath the floors of the Basilica and has survived for 1850 years to be
rediscovered so again is that there's that connection with an event that was
never monumentalized it was never set up like some grand monument to be admired
by future generations it's just a passing moment in time that just happened
to get fossilized in the soil imprint and gave us information that we could
release from the ground over nearly 2,000 years later
you've also got a passion for the Roman period that's obvious but where do you
see and how do you see the Roman footprint in the levels particularly?
well I like to look either side and to contextualize it because it was Sir
Augustine that said that the world is like a book and those that don't travel
only read one page now that's true if you don't travel geographically but
it's true if you don't travel in time so if I only studied the Roman period I
probably wouldn't understand it at all because they stand on the shoulders of
every previous generation and then there are memories of how things were in the
Roman period that shape all future generations including today because
we're still using their alphabet and Latin is hugely important in Welsh and
English so on the levels we've got evidence that Roman sea level was much
lower than it is today nearly 1.8 meters lower on any one given tide will
be like for like about one and three quarter meters lower that's because as
we've come out of the last ice age sea level has slowed down it's rising over
time but it's still rising ever so slightly and there are other sorts of
geological impacts in Britain such as isostatic rebound and the fact that the
east of Britain is slightly tipping in the West rising up ever so slightly but
nonetheless in the Severnestuary and here at Cullien we're about 1.7 meters
higher at any high tide today than it will have been in the past so if you
take off that 1.7 meters across the levels actually most tides would never
have flooded and you would need a sea wall on the levels so we start to
question how old the sea defenses are likely to be and to have been but what
we can find when we dig down on the levels is that all Roman land surfaces
are covered by later inundations which left around half a meter or so to a
meter of the gray heavy alluvium the gray clay from the estuary that you can
see beneath the sea wall anywhere where there's no seagrass growing and once
you get below that half a meter or so you get to the old Roman land surfaces
but you don't get that many field systems there are localized field
systems around Nash water treatment works at Goldcliff and they tend to have
been formed where the Romans cut ditches and when you cut a ditch you get
a bank that goes with it and they form little enclosures or fields but the
banks aren't serious attempts at sea walls they might protect from the odd
couple of feet inundation but then they're not they're not a continuous sea
wall as we would understand it so the focus for them was probably to just
improve the grazing by draining or speeding drainage into the adjacent
ditches and to take the water away and they appear to have been involved in
some serious engineering works because one of the most important Roman finds
from the grant levels was found off Goldcliff Point at Goldcliff Pill on the
edge of the pill and it's a lius limestone flat slab about two to three
feet in height and it's inscribed in Latin probably in the second or third
centuries AD and it says the century of Statorius Maximus of the first cohort so
from this legion at Caillean the second Augustine legion the soldiers of the
century under the century in Statorius Maximus constructed thirty three and a
half paces of something that's all it says the interesting thing about the
stone is it's a very thin slab and the bottom half has not been inscribed so it
the bottom half would have been set in the ground and it would have stood like a
little headstone on the probably an earthwork that had been constructed now
that stone is intriguing because it shows that the Roman army is involved in
an engineering work of some kind construction work at Goldcliff on the
levels the stone was found in the estuary and clay beyond the present sea
war but we know that the sea had taken huge tracts of land even within recent
centuries at Goldcliff so it would have been on land probably when it when it
when it was set up and it's now just beyond the current sea wall which again
tells us something about land loss or gain in the estuary over time and the

the first cohort has double strength century so you could have anything from

something that's not very long actually for 80 to 160 men to be working on just

might suggest that it's actually a Roman construction that they actually

Anecdotally, do you talk to people on the levels and they'll say oh the rene

that is post-roman we know that that seals the Roman landscape underneath.
The two big questions are there are some major waterways the White Wall,
the Black Wall that come down and the Monk's Ditch and the question at the

Romans certainly begin the process that either created them or led to led

Caldecott's got plows by then because it's mentioned they're all taxed
because the Norman view of the feudal system was that all land in Britain has
one landowner it's the king and it's doomsday and this is his terrier of his
tenants so even the lords and the you know the the the sheriffs everybody
beneath him they're all tenants of the king so although we'd look up to them as
the top of the the top branches of the tree they're not they still they're
still tenants of the king and he's got this list now of what's owed to him by
his tenants for for that those lands their mills their fisheries etc their
plows how many people they're working on those farms on the hardwicks etc and
then whatever profit they can make over and above that is obviously theirs
but it's very clear from those early documents how the landscape certainly
in the east is starting to shape up as a more intensively managed landscape but
still along the lines of that time of what it probably was in the Roman
period and beyond they just had in more and more land improvement mechanisms
through drainage and then eventually through to sea defense to to the mix to
further defend the land problem is that the land behind is now fossilized behind
those medieval sea walls but the sea is still rising behind it and of course many
of our great cities were and urban conurbations were trading ports and ports
by definition at sea level but many of them have early foundation dates in the
Roman period like Cullian or in medieval times like Newport Cardiff and Roman
Cardiff and Roman Carmarthens etc but where development was at the medieval
or Roman high tide mark and high and dry it wouldn't necessarily be today
because of sea level rise so there are lessons I think to be learned for future
generations in terms of how we manage our responses to climate change and
environmental change and for the levels perhaps that informs us in terms of the
fact that the only response really in the past was to move in and out of those
areas so like a canoe we're going to find out that just standing there and
commanding the sea to behave is not going to work and it might be necessary
to work out a rationale and a methodology for allowing the sea to take
any land that it requires and to be able to move in and out of the landscape as
change continues because the one norm is change people tend to shy away from it
but the one fact archaeologically and environmentally is change so we need to
learn the lessons from the past to inform the future
Talking about the estuary, I've spoken to a few people who have been out there and follow the tide date
black rock fishery for example they're always finding clay pipes and musket balls etc
and could you tell us about your fishing basket find
the context around that and any other work you've done on it?
yeah I was a student in conservation at Cardiff University in the early 90s and
we had to go to a museum for eight weeks each summer to gain on the job
vocational experience as an internship and because of my great interest in the
geographical area around Newport and the levels I chose one placement at Newport
Museum and Art Gallery working under the great Kate Hunter there the head
conservator at the time and during my internship Nigel Nailing from the
University of Lampeter was working out on the mega level beyond the sea wall
surveying mainly surveying fish traps etc that had been first discovered and
highlighted in the studies that had been undertaken in advance of the
construction of the second seven crossings so they looked at environmental
impact before its construction and archaeological impact if it was going to
destroy archaeology along its path then they were able to record it before
destruction or remove it they looked either side as well because the
construction process could start to change the way the estuary maybe swirled
around and you know scoured or what have you and a fish trap was noted at
mega that had been half sectioned by the tide naturally by the tide which
enabled the insides to be seen where you've got a kind of non return valve a
cone shaped internal wicker structure that prevents the fish can swim down
into the trap but they find it hard to get past the funnel back out again and
because this had been half sectioned naturally by the tide it was a
beautiful example that could be used for teaching of how these things actually
work because when you recreate them you can't see the insides because it's a
round wicker basket so it was being destroyed by the tide which was scouring
it away so it made a perfect project for an undergraduate student because if we
were successful in lifting it Newport Museum would get a 12th or 13th century
original fishing trap from the estuary that would be an excellent display and
teaching resource but if we failed it was going to be destroyed by the sea
anyway so it wasn't really a major part of the project and there were no funds
available as usual story but we had some old casting bandage that's used for
broken arms or broken legs and the sell by date had long gone so again if it was
kind of I think it was a polyurethane that reacted on contact with moist air
ideal for the levels so if it hadn't gone off we're going to use up this
stuff it was a free fish trap if we could get it out so I was sent out there
with a mud sled and given some help and we excavated around the thing we found
the stake which was lifted with it that originally been used to tether it to
hold it in in the estuarine mud and it and its stake were excavated around to
leave them on a pedestal and that's all we could achieve in the first tide
because that part of the level it's very very shallow inclined from the
fan edge down from the sea wall down onto the gravels beyond the mud but the
mud is very thick it's about two feet thick and so the tide comes in quicker
there at mega then it's possible for a man to run on land not alone get across
that mud so if you get trapped by the tide that's it out there you can't get
back so we had a very small window of opportunity to excavate so we just dug
around it the first time I placed my trowel down by the side of the
excavated trap and bandaged the thing round to protect it and then went to get
my trowel and it just gone and I thought well that's easy I put it by there I'll
just fish around in the mud this slurry that's out there see if you can find it
couldn't feel it anywhere that never did find it so I had to abandon the
trowel and most archaeologists become attached to their trowel because you
that was the trowel that dug this or found that and found the funny feature at
Coend so I'd lost this trowel and then we returned the next day after the tide
had gone in gone out and it was low tide again and Lomiel sat on the surface
proud about 12 feet away probably washed up the estuary and back down again was my
trowel bright orange because the iron had turned to iron chloride big crystals
of iron chloride on this work hard and steel trowel and we then dug underneath
the fish trap slid it up onto a mud sled and it was taken in a minibus off to
Newport Museum where it slowly was allowed to dry out and then a future
Cardiff intern after my time with Kate excavated down to the fish trap and
dried it out and stabilized it for display and it's still displayed now in
the gallery with a photograph of it in situ the underside that you can't see in
the case with the half section fish trap with the sort of non return valve and
it's still displayed in the bandage that we used to actually lift it that actually
shows the lifting process and it's resting on the estuarine mud that filled
it when it was in the estuary all preserved this was a little bit of the
seven estuary that's been lifted for display in in Newport Museum and it's
quite a rare example of a of a fish trap of that date the trowel then I put away
and forgot about because it could really be used very well anymore and gone very
orange and when I last saw it a few years later it had just completely turned
to orange powder a solid steel forged trowel had just completely corroded away
and turned to orange powder because of the the aggressive nature of the chlorine
in the seawater that just destroys ironwork so it just shows how aggressive
the environment can be for some things metals especially if they don't become
concreted they just dissolve away basically out there or can do if not
buried in in the clay that sort of encapsulates them but other things such
as organics can become waterlogged in oxygen free environments within that
heavy clay and they can be preserved for thousands of years and the fish trap
probably six or seven hundred maybe eight hundred years old perfectly
preserved because there was no oxygen getting into that mud that could
actually start the decay process and support the bacteria that would then
destroy or the fungi that would then destroy the organic wicker basket so
organics out there the potential for organic preservation is absolutely huge
and that's shown by two of the vessels that have been recovered from out there
the mega pill wreck a medieval vessel the Barlands farm boat a Roman boat
that was recovered from the Gwent Euro Park near the motorway junction at mega
right up on the fan edge there but it probably been sailed up a creek and
abandoned there but because it was filled with the alluvium that heavy gray
clay no oxygen got in and the wood was perfectly preserved and of course the
Newport ship which was similarly filled with the same clay oxygen free
environment completely preserved the wood the Barlands farm boat was fully
excavated by Glamorgan Gwent Archaeological Trust no that that was
whilst I was working I think that was again about the early 90s I think they
excavated that so probably I was still at university at that time or working at
Cardiff University that was excavated by Glamorgan Gwent Archaeological
Trust it's been fully published it's got its own volume but it's it's now
preserved at Newport Museum it's not always on display it depends I think it
may have been moved for display with the Newport ship it has been displayed in
John Frost Square in the museum on the Metsanin gallery in the past or elements

medieval one and the Roman Barlands farm boat are that they look like boats as
does the Newport ship you can see the shape and structure the length and the
construction methods so Newport sits on one of the most important collections of
maritime archaeology in the country and I very much look forward to the day when

because there I can't think of any anywhere better actually to go and see

the moor is the way it was seen and again this Caldecott thing this cold

probably these cold shelters cold cots cold cottages that weren't places of
banishment in in the case of cold harbors they're just seasonal bivouacs or
sort of the equivalent of the camper van or tent where you can be with your
flocks during the summer periods often they don't even have evidence of hearths
for actually cooking there but their shelters that are probably unheated or
largely unheated cold shelters just so that you can be near your flocks or

the early years by treading blackberries and you get the big sort of tub of
blackberry juice which is a good dye and then you can pour it into the bore
holes and then they'd go down into the tunnel and wait for the purple black
berry juice to start coming through and then they could time the flow and work
out the flow through the Great Spring from further upstream at Carwent in the
Neddon Valley and down into the to the pumping station there the he remembers
stories of the whirly holes that once existed in the Neddon Valley. Neddon

them that people could look down into these these whirling this underground
river that sort of came up to the surface at that point of course they
were all filled in as part of the tunnel works and then the water level
slightly dropped once they started pumping out the Great Spring and they're
now lost so these things if not recorded in this way through oral
